bioghist.p: Thorsten Sellin (1896-1994) was a sociologist and one of the pioneers of scientific criminology. He came to prominence in the 1920s and 1930s for his studies in the use of criminal statistics at local, state, national and international levels, and helped draft the U.S. Uniform Criminal Statistics Act in 1944. He received his master's and doctoral degrees from the University of Pennsylvania. He taught at Penn from 1922-1967 and served as chair of the sociology department from 1944-1959. His books include Culture Conflict and Crime (1938) and The Death Penalty (1959).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Thorsten Sellin. Materials include correspondence with colleagues, publishers, and professional organizations; handwritten and typed manuscripts of articles and books, including Slavery and the Penal Code, The Death Penalty, and Crime and Treatment in the Legislation of 1932; addresses and remarks; writings by other criminologists; minutes, notes, and reports of a number of professional organizations, including the International Association of Penal Law, the International Society of Criminology, and the Institute for Research on Crime and Delinquency; and reprints and pamphlets on prisons, delinquency, capital punishment, and many related topics. The collection also includes a small batch of correspondence of Amy J. Sellin; memorabilia, including photographs, cabinet cards, and ephemera from the opening of the Sellin Center in 1985; certificates and plaques; and a framed 1792 broadside in German. There are materials in Swedish, German, Italian, French, and Spanish.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
